Posts.Content: Macchick wrote: Hi, Just wondered if anyone else out there has/had a long rope-like cordy vein under their arm after lumpectomy/SNB.  I was fine 2 weeks after the surgery then started doing arm exercises.  Seems like after the exercises the pain under my arm got a little worse and now when I raise my arm there's this cord-like vein or something under there.  If you've had it does it eventually go away on its own or is this something I should mention to the doctor?  Do things get worse before eventually getting better?  Honestly I'm a little surprised that I felt better 2 weeks ago then now.  Any insights on this are much appreciated.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: rope-like cord in my arm after SNB/lumpectomy Macchick kira

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 07:15AM Macchick wrote: Hi, thanks for the referral.  Tried searching the forums under that and nothing like that came up.  Do you happen to remember when Otter posted this? Did yours resolve on its own?
Posts.Title: rope-like cord in my arm after SNB/lumpectomy Macchick kira

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2009 06:00AM Macchick wrote: Hi, came home from the hosptial yesterday after bilat mx on 2/25.  I think the drain sites actually hurt more than anything at this point.  Did notice some phantom pain already, kind of a weird sensation.  Anyone else out there have phantom pain?  Haven't showered yet, will do that soon.  Had a bit of a rough time with vomiting from the surgery so I've got some abdominal pain from that.  Otherwise, not too bad.  Appreciate all the words of encouragement here.  My best wishes to everyone else recovering from Feb. surgery.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2009 08:11AM Macchick wrote: Hi, I'm having bilateral mx on 2/25, no recon.  Not too worried about it and definitely glad to get the rest of the cancer out.  A little concerned about the possible after-effects of surgery (AWS, lymphedema, pain, numbness, etc.).  Also saw an oncologist yesterday and I don't know why I never realized that when the docs talk about "recurrence" they're not really talking about local recurrence in the breast tissue, they seem to mean distant metastasis or recurrence.  That was a bit jarring to me and also like "duh" why didn't I realize this earlier.  I really hope this all ends with the mastectomies and there's no chemo in my future.  Thanks to everyone on this board - I've learned so much and felt a lot of support, even when I asked questions others have already asked.   Best wishes to everyone else having Feb. surgery.  Gotta love 2009!
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Macchick wrote: Hi, I'm about 6 weeks out from a bilateral mx and just this week I noticed multiple cords running down both sides of my trunk (torso).  Interestingly the cords appeared on my prophylactic side (no nodes removed) as well as the cancer side.  I thought I read somewhere that there might be a higher correlation between axillary cording and arm LE, so given this, do or did those of you out there with truncal lymphedema experience cording in your trunk before, during or after your truncal LE diagnosis?  Also, I'm trying not to be paranoid about LE.  It's just something that hangs over you, albeit not as serious as the possibility of recurrence, but still LE is one thing that I feel I can be on the look out for, and possibly prevent. I've really appreciated this board and all you lovely folks out there willing to share your stuff. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: cording in trunk Macchick jp1b

Posts.Content: Macchick wrote: Hi, I've seen people mention a fat shelf after bilateral mastectomies. What is this?  Would someone mind describing it to me?  I'm asking because I'm having surgery in a couple weeks and had not heard about this before.  Not planning reconstruction ever because I want to have some feeling in my chest.  I'm not a skinny woman but not fat either.  Sort of medium to slightly overweight.   Does this fat shelf, which I'm picturing as not so nice, ever go away?  Sorry if this has been done in another thread but just focusing on the fat shelf topic might be helpful to me. Thanks for any and all replies. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What's a fat shelf? Macchick barbe1958

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 02:53PM Macchick wrote: Hi, thanks everyone for your responses.  Definitely food for thought.  My understanding is that without recon you do regain some feeling as your nerves re-grow.  I went to a support group where one woman who had a TRAM said she can't feel the water under the shower, etc.  That was very jarring to me so I asked someone else if she had feeling in her chest (she had no recon) and she said yes except for about an inch where the scar is, so I thought the chances for sensation to return was better for unreconstructed breasts.  I don't see the breast free thread but will keep trolling until I do.   Glad to have found this site - everyone on it is so supportive and helpful.  Thanks again.
Posts.Title: What's a fat shelf? Macchick barbe1958

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 07:43AM Macchick wrote: I have really found the breastfree.org site very, very helpful as I considered all this.  Thank you for posting the site online.  It was/is a source of hope to me for life beyond the surgery.
Posts.Title: What's a fat shelf? Macchick barbe1958
